problem_text:
19.89. A permutation group is subdegree-finite if every orbit of every point stabiliser
is finite.
Let Ω be countably infinite, and let G be a closed and subdegree-finite
subgroup of Sym(Ω) regarded as a topological group under the topology of pointwise
convergence.
Conjecture: If the minimal degree of G is infinite, then there is some subset of Ω
whose setwise stabiliser in G is trivial.
Note that this conjecture implies Tom Tucker’s well-known Infinite Motion Con-
jecture for graphs.
S. M. Smith
